bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Tom D. Spies, November 8, 1952

div1.p: Hench informs Spies that the dedication of Camp Lazear will be held on Finlay's birthday and “Physicians' Day” in Cuba. He has made his concerns known to Nogueira that Finlay will dominate the affair and that Camp Lazear will be renamed “Parque Finlay.” He suggests Spies visit Camp Lazear when in Cuba to see how the work is progressing.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Tom D. Spies, November 8, 1952
div1.opener:
November 8, 1952
Dr. Tom D. Spies
Nutrition Clinic
Hillman Hospital
Birmingham, Alabama
My dear Tom:
div1.p:
I have been meaning to write to you about the Camp Lazear affair. This
spring when Doctor Nogueira told me that they were really going ahead,
I reacted minimally because so many previous unkept promises and false
starts had made me skeptical but, by golly, this time Doctor Nogueira and
his superiors, presumably Doctor Andreu, the Minister of Health, really went
ahead. They have cleared out part of the cornfield at Camp Lazear, extended
a road, leveled off the ground and are erecting a stone wall to hold certain
medallions honoring Reed, Finlay, Lazear and others and bronze tablets on
which will appear the names of the volunteers, and so on. They had originally
planned to dedicate it on September 20, but were hold up and now plan to dedicate
it on December 3. When the September date fell through, Doctor Nogueira wanted
to dedicate it on November 20, the anniversary of the day the camp was originally
opened but his superiors over-ruled him and chose December 3 which was Finlay's
birthday and “Physician's Day” in Cuba. This date has certain advantages
and certain disadvantages. It has the main advantage that it is “Physicians'
Day,” a day set aside to honor Doctor Finlay in particular and all medical men
in general, a day in which, naturally, physicians will pause for special cere-
monies. It has the disadvantage of being Finlay's birthday. He may dominate
the whole affair.

I have had several communications with Doctor Nogueira this summer, discreetly
and diplomatically urging that they maintain the name Camp Lazear but I
strongly fear that they are going to rename it Parque Finlay. He has re-
peatedly reassured me that Reed's Building No. 1, which the newspapers and the
blue prints erroneously called “caseta de Finlay” will not be misnamed but
will be called Reed's Building No. 1. As to the name, “Parque Finlay,” I
very greatly hate to compromise but in view of the fact that the Cubans are
doing everything toward this dedication and the Americans nothing, I have
felt very helpless and suppose that we may have to accept that compromise
as long as Reed's Building No. 1 is recornized for what it is and as long
as the dedication speeches clearly point out that it was the Americans who
did the work at Camp Lazear, not Doctor Finlay. However this spot is peculiarly
appropriate for a joint memorial since Doctor Finlay did two or three of his
earliest experiments in the main house or quinta of the Finca San Jose. Please
see the enclosed copy of my letter of July 7 and I enclose an extra copy in
case you wish to send it to Mrs. Smith of F.I.M.

During the last four months I have been on the verge several times of “starting
a backfire” and trying to involve others in the affair, Cuban friends who
might make certain that the naming of the Camp is not out of order; however
Dr. Tom D. Spies
- 2 -
November 8, 1952
Doctor Nogueira has been so very cooperative, such a strong force behind this
whole movement and he has reassured me so often that I must not worry, that
they will do the right thing, that I have just not had the courage to go be-
hind his back and demonstrate to him lack of faith. Indeed I do have complete
faith in him and his honorable intentions, but I am not sure to what extent
he may be over-ruled by his superiors.

He has not answered precisely my question as to the intended name of the
project. I strongly suspect we may have to compromise and disappointedly
accept the term “Parque Finlay.” This compromise might be acceptable so
long as Reed's Building No. 1 is properly named.

Nogueira has corresponded with me extensively in regard to the names of the
volunteers to go on the plaques and so on. They have finally made their
decision. I could only make suggestions. Their decision is reasonably
acceptable. They made certain exclusions which are understandable; also
some inclusions which I suggested. When asked about those who should be
invited, I have given them various names, but perhaps not enough. I suggested
official invitations be sent to the President and President-Elect of the
A.M.A., the members of the Walter Reed Memorial Association in Washington,
the Surgeon General or his deputy, the officers of the Walter Reed Society,
perhaps Fishbein, the relatives of the volunteers, also your name and
Smith as well as the State Department and the American Ambassador in Cuba.
I don't think any official invitations have been sent out as yet. There
have been the usual delays and last-minute rush and how extensive will be
their list, I do not know. Although I really don't have time or money to
spare, I hope to fly down for the affair.

Now, Tom, I remember with great pleasure and some concern the conversation
that you, Mrs. Smith and I had about this whole venture. I was hoping, as
you were, that they would drop the matter for the time being and that others
could pick it up do what we wanted; but they most assuredly did not. Things
really began to hum after my January trip and matters were completely out of
my hands because since Reed's Building No. 1 was an official monument, I was
not allowed to do anything privately and they just went ahead.

Tom, I wonder if there isn't a fine opportunity ahead of us. Although they
have torn down much of the original Building No. 1 so that what remains is
more a replica than a restoration, the Cuban Government has gone this far. I
really doubt if they will go any further. Nogueira has promised to save me
as much of the original wood or walling as possible, which I hope to use to
make souvenirs for various interested people and institutions. It is my hope
that with the help of American and perhaps Cuban physicians and friends, we
can now begin to collect money so as to enclose the remains of Building No. 1
in one room of a permanent building, the rest of the building to be a living
memorial (not a museum) to the conquerors of yellow fever, Reed and his as-
sociates, the memorial perhaps to be a little research institution or public
health unit or what have you. I shall not be happy until the little building
has a permanent protection. Now if it seems best merely to have a little
museum building erected over Building No. 1 and while raising funds to do
that, to raise funds for a research project as a living memorial to be used
by F.I.M. and others, that would be an acceptable alternative to me, providing
only that Building No. 1 is permanently enclosed.

May I suggest therefore the following two or three things:
1. Are you going to Havana soon on one of your periodic visits? If so, could
you take time to contact Nogueira without involving me or indicating that
you have perhaps been stimulated by me. Could you not drive out to Camp
Lazear casually, “just happen” to see the activity their and, as a result,
make inquiries of Doctor Nogueira as to what the present plans are? From
there on, you can do whatever seems proper. If you have to have an excuse
to visit Camp Lazear, you might take with you some American or other visitor
“who asked me to show him around where Camp Lazear was.” If you don't know
where it is, telephone Miss Maria Teresa Rojas, Finca San Jose, Calle Real,
Quemados de Marianao, Havana, or drop in on her and her companion, Miss Lydia
Cabrera; both are charming young women. Camp Lazear is at the rear of their
finca on the main street of Marianao.
2. In discussing the matter with Doctor Nogueira, you may be able to offer
him your support to some future project as suggested above. Certainly you
can discuss with him the matter of further American cooperation in the
dedication and make suggestions regarding others to be invited, either
Americans or Cubans in Havana or Americans in the United States.
3. If you find that they are naming the place Parque Finlay instead of
Camp Lazear and if you feel there is any discreet or delicate way in which
you can suggest otherwise, I must leave that up to you. Above all, this
must be handled diplomatically so that we can accomplish our purposes (if
possible) without offending those who are, after all, doing a great deal
to honor the Americans as well as Finlay. Regardless of what we Americans
would like to see done, I was never able to get any Americans to help me
although I have talked about this, written and given many lectures about
it during the last 12 years. Therefore if the Cubans do it not quite the
way we want, I fear we will have to be satisfied up to a point.

In summary, I suspect that having done what they have, that will be the end
of their effort and now is the time for Americans, you and me and others, to
carry on the project.

I am sending you a copy of this letter and also an extra copy of my letter of
July 7 which you may send to Mrs. Smith. If you are going to be in Havana
on December 3 perhaps you, she and I can have a conference regarding future
possibilities. The letter of July 7 is considerably out of date because of
the numerous letters I have had from Doctor Nogueira thereafter.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
Enclosures
P.S.: I have just received your letter of November 3 requesting reprints about
Walter Reed for Dr. J. R. Miller. The ones I enclose herewith are for you and
perhaps Mrs. Smith. By separate post I am sending others for you and Doctor
Miller.
